title: Biden Assails Trump Over Jan. 6 Riot, Efforts to Overturn Election Results
summary: President, congressional Democrats mark anniversary of riot at U.S. Capitol by Trump supporters. WASHINGTON-President Biden assailed former President Donald Trump and a mob of his supporters for the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, using the first anniversary of the attack to rebuke his predecessor's attempts to undermine the 2020 election results.

title: Murders in U.S. Cities Were Near Record Highs in 2021
summary: The surge of killings that began after the pandemic in 2020 remains, though it eased a bit. U.S. cities are facing a sustained surge in homicides, as police departments and mayors' offices tally up crime statistics for 2021 and launch 2022 programs designed to curb gun violence.

title: White House Nominates Airborne Officer to Lead Central Command
summary: Army Lt. Gen. Michael Erik Kurilla would succeed Gen. Frank McKenzie and oversee operations in the Middle East. WASHINGTON-President Biden has nominated a top Army general to be the next commander of U.S. military operations that include the Middle East as the Biden administration's attempt to shift toward China has been complicated by the chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan and Iran's regional and nuclear ambitions.

title: The Endless Loop of Covid-19
summary: The current moment is much like 20 months ago. It is no governmental triumph that this is so.. I was not as impressed as others by the president's speech Thursday in the Capitol. I wanted him to take on a kind of broad-gauged gravity that spoke of the attack of 1/6/21 in a way that didn't make Trump supporters and many Republicans lean away from the first moments but start to lean forward, however reluctantly, even painfully, knowing that what they were hearing was wisdom.

title: The Vaccine Mandate Case May Mark the End of the 'Work-Around' Era
summary: It gives the Supreme Court an opportunity to revive the separation of powers.. Hours after President Biden's Sept. 9 speech announcing a series of vaccine mandates for private-sector employees, his chief of staff, Ron Klain, retweeted an MSNBC anchor's quip that wielding workplace-safety regulation to force vaccinations was "the ultimate work-around." Congress has never enacted a law requiring American civilians to be vaccinated-assuming it even has the constitutional authority to do so, which is doubtful. The Supreme Court hears arguments Friday on two of the mandates, which are likely to meet the same fate as other recent attempts to circumvent Congress that the courts have rejected.

title: Biden's Moment of Truth in Iran
summary: With negotiations likely to fail, he'd better be prepared for a military strike.. Negotiations in Vienna over Iran's nuclear program started this week and quickly stalled-and little wonder. Tehran is striding toward nuclear weapons and has little interest in a diplomatic breakthrough.

title: Supreme Stakes on Vaccine Mandates
summary: The Court's ruling will echo far beyond the current pandemic.. The Supreme Court takes up President Biden's vaccine mandate on Friday, and the stakes are larger than pandemic policy. This is a crucial test of how far the administrative state can go in stretching ambiguous statutes for its own political ends.

title: Donald Trump Can Never Lose
summary: But his refusal to accept defeat has cost many of his supporters a great deal.. Donald Trump did the country-and himself-a favor by canceling the press conference he had planned for Jan. 6. But the press statement he released instead on Thursday underscores that the former President will never admit that he lost the 2020 election, no matter the cost to the country or his supporters.

title: Biden on Democracy for Democrats
summary: The President seems to think democracy is a partisan project.. President Biden has made democracy and its virtues one of his main presidential themes, and much of what he said Thursday on the anniversary of Jan. 6 is worth applauding. Yet as a defense of democracy his speech failed, and it's worth noting why.

title: A Sanctuary City for Crime
summary: Manhattan's new district attorney undercuts Mayor Adams's initiative to make New York safe again.. Eric Adams took office as mayor of New York promising to get crime under control. He has his work cut out for him in Manhattan, where the new district attorney, Alvin Bragg, began his tenure by instructing prosecutors not to do their jobs.

title: China Takes Lithuania as an Economic Hostage
summary: Its trade retaliation over Taiwan is wreaking havoc with global supply chains.. Beijing has developed a reputation for blocking imports from countries it wants to punish. Australian wine became a target last year. Now China is punching back at Lithuania, which recently allowed Taiwan to open a representative office in Vilnius. But here's the new twist: China is holding up not only Lithuanian imports, but all imports that include Lithuanian parts. The effects are rippling across Europe.

title: Remote Instruction Is Bad for Mom and Dad
summary: When schools forced kids to stay home, parents reported an uptick in mental-health issues.. We've heard a lot about how school closings affect children, but what about parents left scrambling for child care and in-person learning options? In 2020, such disruptions disproportionately caused women to leave the labor market to take care of their children at home.

title: Oil, Uranium Prices Jump Amid Kazakhstan Unrest
summary: The resource-rich country accounts for about 40% of the world's uranium output, which it sells to utilities in the U.S. and elsewhere. summary: Members look in vain for a coup plot but ignore Congress's own security failures.. Select committees come and go, with varying impact. The growing risk of Nancy Pelosi's January 6 Committee is that it will be remembered for all the wrong reasons.

summary: Whom should you tell, how long should people quarantine, and when should you call your doctor? Here are answers to your questions.. title: 'A Hero' Review: Bright Lies, Murky Truths
summary: In Asghar Farhadi's latest, a prisoner turns a possible solution to his problems into further woes through a series of fabrications. The hero of "A Hero" looks heroic from the first moment we see him full-face. He's strikingly handsome, with a trim beard, piercing eyes and a radiant smile. That will change-not only his looks but how we perceive him. Almost everyone, and everything we think we know about them, changes constantly in Asghar Farhadi's latest morality tale, in Persian with English subtitles; it's his finest work since his Oscar-winning "A Separation" a decade ago. People do the right thing, then the wrong thing, then things that are right for the wrong reasons or wrong for even wronger reasons. Half the time they have little or no idea what they're doing because their good side doesn't know what their bad side is concocting. This astute, subversively funny film fills a broad canvas. Mainly, though, it's about long division, the all-too-human state of being permanently and unwittingly split down the middle. (Currently in select theaters, "A Hero" will move to Amazon Prime Video on Jan. 21.)

title: 'Pivoting' Review: A New Spin on Resolutions
summary: After the death of a friend, three women try to reinvent themselves in Fox's sitcom. All sitcoms have a central joke, a kind of trunk that keeps them stable and erect through their seasonal lifespans and on which gags are hung like ornaments. At first blush, "Pivoting," which makes its debut Sunday on Fox, seems based on the barely arguable point that women are asked to do far more than is possible, men are asked to do far less, and the math is somehow hilarious.

title: 'The Streets of New York' Review: Gripping Musical Melodrama
summary: The Irish Repertory Theatre scores once again in its revival of Charlotte Moore's song-filled adaptation of Dion Boucicault's 19th-century play. New York

title: 'Ailey' Review: Peeking Behind the Curtain of a Choreographer's Creative Mind
summary: Dance-world luminaries shed light on the singular choreographer in this 'American Masters' documentary. The problem with being Alvin Ailey was being Alvin Ailey. "Sometimes your name becomes bigger than yourself," says the dancer-choreographer Carmen de Lavallade of her late friend and colleague. "Alvin Ailey: Do you really know who that is, or what that is?" Jamila Wignot's moving and poetic documentary portrait, "Ailey," provides answers, while making clear that its subject had the same questions.

summary: Before Omicron surge, president said in July the nation was 'closer than ever to declaring our independence from a deadly virus'. WASHINGTON-As Covid-19 cases climb across the U.S., President Biden and his administration are preparing Americans to accept the virus as a part of daily life, in a break from a year ago when he took office with a pledge to rein in the pandemic and months later said the nation was "closer than ever to declaring our independence from a deadly virus."

title: What Role Should Mark Zuckerberg Play in U.S. Elections?
summary: The Facebook founder's funding of election administration may be constitutionally protected.. In "No Facebook Funding for Elections" (op-ed, Dec. 31), Tarren Bragdon and Joe Horvath endorse a ban on private funding for public election administration. The problem they target-partisan spending by public officials-may be real, but their proposed ban is a significant infringement on free speech. Contributions by the private sector, whether by Mark Zuckerberg or Charles Koch, should be fully protected. But public-sector recipients of those contributions must not spend them in a politically discriminatory manner.

title: How Financial Advisers Get Paid: What the Readers Think
summary: An earlier Ask Encore column suggested many retirees might be paying too much. Many investors agreed; financial advisers, not so much.. Excellent article about financial advisers and fees. Why advisers get paid according to assets under management is a mystery.

title: Fluvoxamine and the Fate of Orphan Drugs
summary: We need new data on the drug and the zealous advocacy that comes with a potential for great fortune.. I'm glad Allysia Finley highlighted the Lancet article by Gilmar Reis and colleagues ("Is Fluvoxamine the Covid Drug We've Been Waiting For?" op-ed, Dec. 29). But the results are not as simple as she described. The clinical benefits were seen in patients treated within seven days, outpatient only, and with a risk factor. The study participants, however, do not align with this protocol based on Table 1 in the Lancet article, calling into question the internal validity of the study's results.

title: Stricter Mileage Rules Beget Better Cars
summary: We were once told that removing lead from gas would result in engine failures. But the sky never fell.. Regarding Jonathan Lesser's op-ed "The EPA's Mileage Standards Are a Stealth Electric-Vehicle Mandate" (Dec. 29): Mileage requirements have resulted in better cars. Engines are smaller and more efficient, and transmissions are better at getting performance out of them, with six to 10 gears now common, or continuously variable transmissions in common and well-reviewed cars.

title: Legal Cannabis Is Coming. Better Now Than Later.

summary: President Biden could demonstrate his seriousness by taking action.. He could probably find some striking teachers pretty easily.

title: 'Firepower' Review: The Gunpowder Revolution
summary: How a new class of weapons upended the foundations of Western society and led to a race for technological supremacy that continues today.. No one knows exactly when gunpowder, a Chinese invention dating to the ninth century, arrived in the West. The English natural philosopher and cleric Roger Bacon described its formula-sulphur, charcoal, saltpeter-in the late 13th century; it did not take long for that new knowledge to be put to awesome use. Protocannons known as bombards were monstrous and crude but devastating. Mons Meg, a siege bombard cast in the Low Countries in 1449, could throw a 300-pound chipped-stone ball a distance of 2 miles at a speed of 700 miles an hour-just shy of the speed of sound. Knocking down castle walls had never been so easy. Within a century of their first appearance in the early 1300s, these new engines of war ousted the English from France, the Moors from Spain and the Byzantine dynasty from Constantinople.

title: The Big Men's Fashion Trend of 2022? Dressing Like a Tween
summary: 'Kidcore'-a fad that sees adult men conjure their tweenage years with expressive, if juvenile, outfits-has thrived during the pandemic. Why the style is resonating and how to strike a somewhat age-appropriate balance.. IT HAD BEEN a youthful year for men's fashion. Cutesy charm necklaces often encircled the necks of Pete Davidson and Justin Bieber, making those shlumpy style icons-and paparazzi favorites-look like they'd been sprung from summer camp. Last November, Washington Wizard Kyle Kuzma pulled up to the locker room in a pink Raf Simons sweater with gigundo sleeves, calling to mind a kid wearing his big brother's hand-me-downs. And fashion companies minted adult-size clothes with serious Children's Place overtones. British label JW Anderson's spring offering was littered with sweaters and other pieces in cutesy strawberry prints, while Urban Outfitters carries a "doodle" hoodie covered in infantilizing smiley faces.

title: Buccaneers Release Antonio Brown After Injury Allegations Against the Team
summary: After the star wide receiver left midway through a game Sunday, leading to his split with the team, he accused the Buccaneers of pressuring him to play through an ankle injury. title: The Omicron LeBrons Want to Stay in the NBA

title: How Marxism 'Won' the War of Ideas
summary: The late Italian writer Augusto Del Noce saw its ironic triumph coming in the West.. When I was a teenager, I spent a year meeting weekly with a psychiatrist. In the end, talking about myself bored even me. But the value of the sessions was real. They gave me, at a turbulent time in my life, a chance to speak honestly and deeply with another human being without the hand-wringing of my family or the burden of guilt. For many, psychiatrists and other mental-health counselors have replaced the clergy as healers of the soul. Today, science too often and too easily seems to preclude the hunger for God. But at least modern therapists share something important-their humanity-with their patients. Both are creatures of flesh and blood.

title: Djokovic Pays for Australia's Unforced Covid Errors
summary: A vaccine mandate bars the world's top tennis player.. Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios is notorious for on-court meltdowns. His government seems to be following his example. He won't be able to compete in the Australian Open unless he wins his appeal.

summary: U.S. regulators will release proposals on climate and diversity; China may update its emissions-trading system; the EU mulls the meaning of green. Companies and investors are facing crucial sustainability policy decisions in 2022 that will shape the way they operate around the world.

title: New York's Omicron Surge Points to a Wave of Mild Cases
summary: Hospitals warn that staff are exhausted, which hampers isolation, care of Covid-19 patients. Fewer New York residents are seeing the worst outcomes of Covid-19 in its latest surge compared with earlier waves, a potential harbinger of what other highly vaccinated parts of the country will experience, health officials say.

title: Despite Theranos and Other Disasters, Startup Founders Have More Power Than Ever
summary: A flood of money means it is a great time for entrepreneurs, even with Elizabeth Holmes's criminal conviction over her failed blood-testing company. The verdict in the criminal trial of Elizabeth Holmes completes a chapter in the tangled tale of Theranos. Meanwhile, the power that founders wield over startups-for better or worse-is only growing.

title: Are Foldable Smartphones Finally Cool?
summary: After years of slow sales, there are early signs that the flexible-screen technology pioneered by Samsung is gaining wider consumer acceptance. Will 2022 be the year when foldable smartphones go mainstream?

title: North Korea Says It Tested Hypersonic Missile
summary: The technology is some of the latest being developed by the U.S., China and Russia. Pyongyang's appears to be in the early stages.. SEOUL-North Korea said it hit a target with a hypersonic missile, as the country seeks to put itself in the small club of countries developing the technology.

title: Novak Djokovic Denied Entry to Australia Ahead of Australian Open
summary: The 20-time major champion had received a medical exemption to get around a ban on unvaccinated travelers before government authorities stepped in.. Tennis superstar Novak Djokovic's bid to play in the Australian Open-with a medical exemption to get around vaccination requirements-appeared to end on Wednesday as government authorities canceled his visa to enter the country.

title: Russia-Led Force to Help Quell Kazakhstan Unrest
summary: Resume Subscription. MOSCOW-Mass protests in Kazakhstan over an increase in fuel prices have prompted an alliance of former Soviet states to send troops to help support the country's president after the government of the Central Asian nation resigned and the leader imposed a state of emergency.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How Those Who Were There Look Back on Jan. 6 Capitol Riot
summary: Resume Subscription. The storming of the U.S. Capitol by Trump supporters on Jan. 6, 2021, continues to reverberate in the halls of Congress. Lawmakers, police officers and Hill staffers who were there face reminders when they go to work, passing rooms that were barricaded and windows that were shattered. In recent interviews, some of them detailed their memories and how they view the riot and its significance now.

title: WarnerMedia, ViacomCBS Explore Sale of CW Network
summary: Nexstar Media Group is among the suitors for CW Network, sources say. AT&T Inc.'s WarnerMedia and ViacomCBS Inc. are exploring a possible sale of a significant stake or all of the CW Network, which they jointly own, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: CDC Recommends First Covid-19 Boosters for 12- to 15-Year-Olds
summary: The adolescents will be able to get Pfizer-BioNTech shots with the CDC sign off. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended Covid-19 boosters for 12- to 15-year-olds, making the doses available to the adolescents for the first time.

title: Anger at Xi'an Lockdown Spreads in China
summary: Account of woman who lost her unborn baby in the eighth month of pregnancy after being denied medical attention prompts outcry. Authorities in the Chinese city of Xi'an relented in some of their pandemic restrictions after a nationwide outcry over the account of a woman who lost her unborn baby in the eighth month of pregnancy after being denied medical attention for hours.

title: Chicago Public Schools Cancel Classes After Teachers Vote Against In-Person Instruction
summary: Mayor Lori Lightfoot says schools are safe and calls teacher vote an illegal job action. CHICAGO-Chicago Public Schools canceled classes Wednesday and Thursday after the teachers union voted late Tuesday to stop providing in-person instruction, citing the latest surge in Covid-19 that has sent cases to record levels in the city.

title: Inside a Covid-19 School Closing: A Pennsylvania Superintendent Agonizes Over Going Remote
summary: Resume Subscription. Teachers calling in sick from Covid-19 are prompting superintendents across the country to close schools and move classes online, forcing parents to scramble for child care and reorder work schedules.

title: Nike Sues Lululemon for Patent Infringement Over Mirror Fitness Technology
summary: Sneaker giant says apparel maker's fitness device and apps use technology invented and patented by Nike. Nike Inc. filed a lawsuit alleging Lululemon Athletica Inc.'s Mirror home-fitness device and applications infringe on the sneaker company's portfolio of patents.

title: Software Company Ousts Co-Founder for Sending Anti-Semitic Email
summary: David Bateman was asked to resign hours after sending the email, which also had false information about Covid-19 vaccines and testing. Utah software company Entrata Inc. said it ousted its chairman after he sent an anti-Semitic email to dozens of business leaders and politicians that stated false information about Covid-19 vaccines and testing.
